etymologies: early 17th century. From post-classical Latin magistrandus, gerundive of magistrare to confer a master's degree on, specific application of classical Latin magistrāre; compare -and

definitions: Originally, in Scottish Universities: an Arts student in the fourth or highest class. Subsequently: any undergraduate in the fourth or final year.

notes.text: Now only in use at St Andrews: revived in the late 19th century.
